For now, Fadell‚Äôs latest tour de force stands as a friendly ambassador for a future that‚Äôs still far away for most of us, and a glimpse of how we might yet wind up with something useful from what so far has been a blockchain of fools. 12/13

The Ledger-ites admit, though, that no matter how slick Stax is, it interacts with systems that have massive barriers to entry and existential questions of reliability. Still, they believe in the promise of crypto and the necessity of self-custody. 11/13 https://t.co/rQ8X4YYxKf

The implosion of FTX capped off a convulsive year for digital assets, yet the folks at Ledger say it‚Äôs been a vindication for their company. People who had been holding digital assets in exchanges are moving them to hardware wallets. 10/13

But a delightful wallet can only do so much; it‚Äôs not going to win over people who struggle through 40,000 word crypto explainers in allegedly plain language and still can‚Äôt figure it out. Does Ledger really believe it can transform the industry? 9/13 https://t.co/YgjDB8Knv7

In Fadell‚Äôs mind, the wallet should be about the size of a credit card and have a touchscreen. He saw people owning more than one. He came up with the idea of having magnets to snap multiple units into a tidy stack like a cash bundle. 8/13 https://t.co/YkrNLrfU4Z

As the guy who swept away the pain points of first-generation MP3 players and thermostats, Fadell was quick to understand the shortcomings of Ledger‚Äôs wallet: its screen was tiny, it lacked a keypad, setup took a glacial 30 minutes. 7/13

Fadell met with Gauthier at a Paris caf√©. They agreed that Ledger‚Äôs next product needed to have broader appeal. ‚ÄúI want to be the chief designer on that,‚Äù Fadell told Gauthier when he hit on a vision for Stax. The CEO immediately agreed. 6/13

Pascal Gauthier, an early investor, believed that a fusty mentality was hindering the company's growth. He wanted to mix Ledger‚Äôs rigid security focus with Steve Jobs-level creativity. In 2018, he took part in a boardroom uprising that made him CEO. 5/13 https://t.co/riZtKpZxTi

But in the weeks leading up to Ledger‚Äôs reveal of Stax, the arc of crypto has bent into a dunk tank. Timing, as product gurus know, is everything. Stax might be coming at the perfect moment, but it could as easily be the worst. 4/13

Fadell is reinventing this gadget. He believes that by giving the Ledger Stax the panache of the hottest consumer gadgets, he will be able to redirect the crypto field, just as he helped kick off digital music and the smart home. 3/13 https://t.co/ga8mZwKVZ1

When you own cryptocurrency your balance is protected solely by a private key that can be devilishly hard to keep safe. Ledger‚Äôs wallets act as tiny vaults‚Äìa physical lock for digital secrets‚Äìbut so far they‚Äôve been off-putting. Much like crypto.  2/13

üßµTony Fadell led the team that created Apple‚Äôs iPod, and cofounded the Google-acquired company Nest. Now he‚Äôs building the Ledger Stax, a hardware wallet he hopes will attract more non-nerds to Web3.  https://t.co/Bjn4aYBVdI
